loans.name: Kluvi Esther

texts.en:
Kluvi Esther A. sells food. She is married and has 3 children. Business is doing very well, and she wishes to increase sales. She is running out of stock.

She is asking for additional capital to buy more food items for sale.

loans.use: This loan will be used for additional capital to buy more food items for sale.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys Y. sells used clothing. She is married and has 2 children. Her business is doing very well, and now  she wishes to increase sales. She is running out of stock.

She is asking for additional capital to buy more clothing for sale.

loans.use: This loan will be used as additional capital to buy more clothing for sale.

loans.name: Gakuweebwa Munno Women's Group

texts.en: Christine N. is the chairperson of Gakuweebwa Munno women’s group in Lugazi. She has a 10-year-old business, a mobile shop, selling new clothes for men, women and children at daily markets locally termed as “mubuulo.” With this kind of business, men and women in the same trade contribute and hire a Fuso truck that moves them every day of the week to these markets. She buys her stock from Kampala, usually on Thursday and Saturday. She is happy with this business, though at times there are setbacks due to the changing seasons. But the business has kept her going, especially now that her husband works and stays in Kenya and she has to buy the food and cover other immediate needs at home. She has four children and cares for one orphan. Her dream is to see her children grow into responsible citizens.

loans.use: To buy more clothes from Kampala to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth B. is married with two children. Her grocery business is doing well and she wishes to increase her sales.

As she is running out of stock, she is asking for additional capital to buy more food items for sale.

loans.use: To buy more food items

loans.name: Safa

texts.en:
Safa S., who is married with two children, prepares and sells a food dish called ‘Wakye’ that is made of cooked rice and beans. It is very nutritious and love by Ghanaians. Her business is doing well and she wishes to increase the food production and sales.

She is asking for additional capital to buy more food items for the food production and sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items for food production and sales

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria A. is married with two children. Her grocery business is doing well and she wishes to increase her food production and sales.

She is asking for $225 as additional capital to buy more food items for the food production and sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris S., who is married with two children, sells second hand clothes. Her business is doing well and she wishes to increase her sales.

As she is running out of stock, she is asking for additional capital to buy more clothing to sell.

loans.use: To buy more clothing

loans.name: Suzan Namulindwa's Gakuweebwa Munno Group

texts.en: Suzan N. and Joyce M. are members of Gakuweebwa Munno women’s group in Lugazi. For 10 years, Suzan has been selling new clothes at daily markets called "mubuulo." She buys the clothes from Kampala. She is married with four children plus three relatives in her care, and she would like a loan to help with buying more clothes for her stock. Joyce has a retail shop in Kakonko, Lugazi, that sells sugar, soap, salt, beans and biscuits, and she would like a loan to help with restocking her shop so as to attract more customers. Joyce is married with five kids and cares for two of her in-laws.

loans.use: To buy more clothes, sugar, soap, salt, biscuits and beans to sell

loans.name: Yeourn Chhun Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Yeourn C. is the group leader of five members in Chro Moh Chrouk Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a subsistence farmer who earns only a small income to support her family. Thus, Mrs. Yeourn C. needs to start another pig breeding business and so she has asked for a loan to buy pigs. Mrs. Yeourn C. is 59 years old and is married with two children, one of whom is a construction worker and the other is studying at school. Her husband, Mr. Lot Chan, is also a farmer who always assists his wife in the field to improve their life together.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy pigs for breeding

loans.name: Phat Leng Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phat L. is a farmer who cultivates the rice field next to Chro Moh Chrouk Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Phat L.’s family plans a big wedding ceremony for her first daughter, but Mrs. Phat L. does not have enough money to buy a new house for the wedding. She has therefore decided to ask for a loan for this purpose.

Mrs. Phat L. is the group leader. She is 48 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory. The remaining children attend school. Her husband, Mr. Phuok Kim, is also a farmer. Mrs. Phat L. has never had a loan before but now she needs one for her daughter’s wedding. In Cambodian tradition, everyone must get married in order to live together without embarrassment. If a couple lives together without being married, the parents, relatives and neighbors will be ashamed.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a new house for a wedding ceremony.

payments.comment: This group has an End of Term loan. This means that principal is due at the end of the loan. AMK allows for pre-payments, thus some the members might pay some principal before the end of the loan. So Mr. Phai Nam decided to pay $13 in advance.
This is the repayment on June 2008.

loans.name: Tausi's Nguvu Moja B Group

texts.en:
Tausi, age 40, is married with 2 children (ages 20 and 15). In order to support her family, Tausi is involved in multiple trades. She works as a hair stylist, and sells fabrics and peanuts on the street. She started selling peanuts in 2002 and fabrics in 2004. She buys the fabrics in Dar es Salaam and takes them to other parts of the country, such as to the capital of Dodoma, to sell. In Dar es Salaam, she sells these fabrics door-to-door. From all her work, she makes a monthly profit of about $90.

In the past, Tausi has taken two loans in order to buy more fabrics to sell. She now hopes for a new loan for the same purpose. She will share this loan with her subgroup, whose members have clothing and general item businesses. They belong to a loan group whose member guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Tausi is on the right.

loans.use: To buy more fabrics to sell

loans.name: Augustina's Dira Group

texts.en:
Augustina, age 44, is married with four children. To support her family, she started a small cafe in 1994 and also a small beverage shop in 2007 where she sells soft drinks and alcoholic beverages. She works from 6am to 10pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $210 from her sales.

In the past, Augustina has taken a loan in order to open her beverage shop and to also pay school fees for her children. She now hopes for a new loan for the same purpose. She will share this loan with her subgroup, whose members have cafe, general shop, and stationary businesses. They belong to a loan group whose members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Augustina is on the right.

loans.use: To buy more beverage stock and to pay school fees

loans.name: John

texts.en:
M. John is multi trader who sells all kinds of electrical items. He is married and has 2 children. His wife prepares a native food called bunku to sell. Business is doing very well, and he wants to increase sales. He is running out of stock.

He is requesting a loan of $400 to buy more clothing for sale.

loans.use: To buy electronics

loans.name: Stephen Kwesi

texts.en:
Stephen Kwesi P. is an electrician, who is married with two children. His business is doing well, but he wishes to improve the quality of his service conditions.

He is asking for additional capital to buy more electrical materials for his business.

loans.use: To buy more electrical materials

loans.name: Jones

texts.en:
Jones M. is a fisherman who is married, with two children. His business is doing well, but his fishing net is very old and he wishes to buy a new one.

He is asking for additional capital to buy more fishing materials for his business.

loans.use: To buy more fishing materials

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert E. is a single parent with one child. His repair business is doing well, but his equipment is out of date and he would like to replace it.

He is asking for additional capital to buy more equipment for his repair work.

loans.use: To buy more equipment for repair work.

loans.name: Williams Kenneth

texts.en:
Williams Kenneth N. is an electronic repairman. His business is doing well, but his equipment is out of date and he would like to replace it.

He is asking for additional capital to buy more equipment to facilitate his repair work.

loans.use: To buy more equipment to facilitate repair work

loans.name: Elizabeth Anna

texts.en:
Elizabeth Anna T. is married with three children. She has a business selling sewing materials that is doing well, but she wishes to increase her sales.

As she is running out of stock, she is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more sewing materials to sell.

loans.use: To buy more sewing materials

loans.name: Maria Cleofe's Group

texts.en:
Maria, Juanita, and Rosa have been members of the "Alegria Huamanga" community bank for 1-2 years. In that time, they have learned to be punctual and responsible. In addition, they have found support and learned to value themselves.

Maria is forty-four years old and has six children. Maria has owned a small grocery store for the past three years. Before that, she had a printing shop in the center of town, but the competition was too great and she decided to switch businesses.

Juanita is thirty-eight years old. She lives with her partner and their two children. Juanita has a small store and travels around the region buying and selling different products, depending on the season. She uses loans to smooth out slow spots between seasons.

Rosa is thirty years old. She is married and does not have any children. Rosa has been selling replacement car parts for one and a half years.

Maria, Juanita, and Rosa need loans of 2000, 600, and 600 soles (2.8 soles to $1). They will use these loans to buy increasingly large quantities of merchandise.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest-earning savings account each associate has. Maria, Juanita, and Rosa plan to use their savings to support children that are studying at the local university, visit a daughter who is living in Ayacucho, and to take a vacation in Lima.

They dream that their children will grow up strong and healthy, be able to attend the university, and become professionals.

loans.use: To buy increasingly large quantities of merchandise.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Adelaide

texts.en: E. Adelaide sells medicine. She is married and has no child. Business is doing very well she wishes to increase sales. She is running out of stock. She is requesting a loan to buy more medicine to sell.

loans.use: To buy more medicine to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Cobbina Ato

texts.en: Cobbina Ato A., who is married with no children, is an electrician. His repair and phone sales business is doing well, but he wishes to increase sales. Cobbina Ato is asking for $525 as additional capital to buy more equipment to facilitate his repair work and to sell more phones.

loans.use: To buy more equipment to facilitate repair work

loans.name: Jesucita's Group

texts.en:
Alejandrina, Jesusita and Angelica are all members of the same village bank at FINCA. All three of them agree that being members of FINCA has reinforced the values of punctuality, responsibility, saving; values that they believe are important in the growth of their businesses.

Alejandrina is forty-two years old and has four children -- three boys and one girl -- ranging from six to twenty three years old. She was a member of FINCA in 1993, left for two years, and rejoined in 1995. She has been receiving support from FINCA ever since. Alejandrina has a business selling all kinds of vegetables from a stand in the local market. She used to sell vegetables in her village in the country before moving to the capital city of Ayacucho, Huamanga.

Jesusita is 33 years old and has 2 children, a boy of 8 and a girl of 16. Jesusita has been a part of FINCA for 18 years. Jesusita has a little store where she sells food staples, such as pasta, grains, soft drinks and candy.

Angelica is 26 years old and has a new, 10-month-old baby girl. She recently joined FINCA in December of 2007. Before moving to Ayacucho, she was living in Lima and studying to become a nurse, but moved to Ayacucho with her new husband to raise a family here. Now she serves lunch from her house as her business.

Alejandrina, Jesusita and Angelica need loans of 750, 900, and 600 soles (3 soles = 1 dollar) to buy more vegetables, rice, potatoes, pasta, lemons and other foods to expand their businesses.

Alejandrina, Jesusita and Angelica all have dreams of someday improving their houses. They dream that their children will become professionals. Angelica also plans to complete her nursing degree.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables, rice, potatoes, pasta, lemons and other foods to expand their businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 22, 2008)
Correction due to underpayment for business 47642

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en: Alexander B. is married with four children. He has a business selling home appliances that is doing well, but he is running out of stock. He is asking for additional capital to buy more home appliances in order to increase his sales.

loans.use: To buy more home appliances

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Maria's Group

texts.en:
Maria, Rosa and Eugenia are all members of the same village bank at the FINCA branch in Huamanga, Ayacucho. All three of them agree that being members of FINCA has taught them important values, such as punctuality, responsibility, and saving, as well as learning how to expand their businesses.

Maria is 69 years old and married and has three grandchildren who are 2, 9, and 12 years old. She has been a member of FINCA for 20 years. Maria has a small street stand where she sells fruit, candy and soft drinks. She has been in the food business for 35 years.

Rosa is 29 years old and lives with her husband. She has three children, two girls and a boy, all of whom are under the age of 13. Rosa has been a member of FINCA for 7 years. Rosa has a business working with cars. She sells car oil in her store and also repairs damaged cars. Before she was 18, she sold food, but she changed businesses to proviD. more opportunities for herself and her children.

Eugenia is 54 and is single. She has 6 adult children, 3 male and 3 female, all in their thirties. She has been a member of FINCA for 5 years. Eugenia is a professional seamstress and knitter, and sells clothing, such as sweaters. She also sells cheese. Before moving to Huamanga, the capital city of Ayacucho, she used to sell food in the countrysiD. of Ayacucho. She moved from her hometown to Huamanga because of terrorism.

Maria, Rosa and Eugenia need loans of 1000, 600, and 1,500 soles (3 soles = 1 dollar) to buy soft drinks and cookies, products to fix and improve cars, and material, such as yarn and wool.to buy soft drinks, cookies, products to fix and imporve cars, and materials such as yarn and wool.

All three women dream of seeing their children become professionals. They hope to proviD. them with a good education.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks and cookies, products to fix and improve cars, and material, such as yarn and wool.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 22, 2008)
Correction due to overpayment for business 47644

loans.name: Bassaw Domnic

texts.en:
Bassaw Domnic A. is an electronics repairman who is married with three children. His business is doing well but his equipment is outdated and he would like to replace it.

He is asking for additional capital to buy more equipment to facilitate his repair work.

loans.use: To buy more equipment to facilitate repair work

loans.name: De La Buena Esperanza Group

texts.es:
Every three weeks, on Mondays, the women of De La Buena Esperanza gather in the Barranche community to attend Friendship Bridge’s repayment or savings meetings.

These women are mostly in the business of livestock breeding. The breeding of chickens, pigs and cows is a good business. Some of them breed chickens exclusively, while others combine the breeding of different animals. In actuality, it really depends on the demand in the market.

The women of De La Buena Esperanza had previously requested a loan from Friendship Bridge. They believe that receiving a loan is a great idea because it helps them greatly in their business being that this loan is one of the few - if not the only - source of credit to which they have had access.

Some of them believe that a loan is a tool they can use to, one, come out of poverty, and two, gain a certain independence. This is due to the fact that when they invest the loan in their business, and it grows along with its utility, the women will have extra income for them to invest or spend at their disposition.

However, the battle to escape poverty is long and harsh. For the time being, the women must earn enough to cover their families’ baS. needs. They mentioned that covering their household’s baS. expenses was the most difficult for them.

Through Kiva, you can help these women fight against poverty. Please support them in their fight!

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

Cada tres semanas los días lunes las mujeres De la Buena Esperanza se juntan en la comunidad de Barranche para asistir a las reuniones de repago o de ahorro de Friendship Bridge.

Este grupo de señoras se dedican mayormente a la crianza de animales. La crianza de pollos, cerdos y toros es un buen negocio. Algunas señoras se dedican exclusivamente a la crianza de pollos, mientras que otras combinan la crianza de distintos animales. Realmente, depende de la demanda del mercado.

Las mujeres De la Buena Esperanza ya habían solicitado un crédito anteriormente con Friendship Bridge. Ellas piensan que solicitar un crédito es una gran idea porque las ayuda mucho en su negocio, ya que este crédito es una de las muy pocas, sino lo única, fuente de crédito a las cual ellas han tenido acceso.

Algunas piensan que el crédito es una herramienta que ellas utilizan para, uno salir de la pobreza y dos para ganar cierta independencia. Esto se debe a que cuando ellas invierten el crédito en su negocio y este crece al igual que sus utilidades, las señoras van a tener un dinero extra que ellas pueden invertir o gastar a su disposición.

Sin embargo, la lucha de salir de la pobreza es dura y larga. Por el momento, las señoras tienen que ganar lo suficiente para cubrir las necesidades básicas de su familia. Ellas mencionaron que cubrir los gastos de la canasta básica era lo más duro para ellas.

Ustedes por medio de Kiva pueden ayudar a estas señoras a luchar contra la pobreza. ¡Acompáñenlas en su lucha!

loans.use: Invest in the breeding of animals such as chickens, pigs and cows.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Friendship Bridge - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel H. is married, with four children. He has an electronics repair business that is doing well, but his equipment is old and out of date and he would like to replace it.

Daniel is asking for additional capital to buy more equipment to facilitate his repair work.

loans.use: To buy more equipment to facilitate repair work

loans.name: Cirila

texts.en:
Cirila has been a part of the El Roble community bank for the past 9 years. She is 53 years old, is married, and has one child.

Cirila sells coca leaves at different fairs in the region of Ayacucho. The coca leaf is an important herb for the farmers in the countrysiD. of Ayacucho. Cirila also sells candy and cigarettes at wholesale prices. She acquires the products in different cities of the Ayacuchan region of Huancayo and then distributes the products to different stores and markets.

Cirila needs a loan of 2,500 soles to buy more cigarettes and candy to sell.

She dreams that her child will become a professional. She also wants to add a second story to her home and rent out rooms.

loans.use: To buy cigarettes and candy to sell.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: De La Buena Esperanza 2 Group

texts.es:
The women of De La Buena Esperanza #2 are also in the livestock industry. In the community of Barranche, the business is very profitable being that despite many of them working in it, they continue to invest in their respective businesses due to the demand in their products.

They believe that the loans they receive are of utmost importance being that without said injection of funds, their businesses would be unable to prosper. Fortunately, they were able to pay their past loans easily. One important detail worth mentioning is that previously, in rural communities, those that offered the loans charged up to 10% interest per day. For this reason, institutions like Friendship Bridge are of vital importance to microfinance being that now the women can have dependable access to loans.

These ladies are currently working in the livestock breeding industry. Many of them are breeding chickens, pigs and bulls. The animals they breed depend on the demand in the market. However, the dream of some of them is to learn to make cakes, finger foods and handicrafts. This is because they want to diversify their businesses so that they do not have to depend on one sole source of income. The dream of some others is to pay off their loan, then take out another one that allows them to purchase more livestock.

This group of women is very enthusiastic, and for that reason we must give them wings in the form of a loan. They have the disposition to work hard, since they have been doing it their whole lives to survive the harsh conditions of poverty. Please support them in this development process so that they may progress.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn G., Kiva Volunteer.

Las mujeres de la Buena Esperanza #2 también pertenecen a la industria de la ganadería. En la comunidad de Barranche el negocio es muy rentable, ya que a pesar de que muchas señoras trabajan en ganadería ellas siguen invirtiendo en su mismo negocio debido a la demanda que tienen por sus productos.

Ellas creen que los préstamos que ellas reciben le son de suma utilidad ya que sin dicha infusión de dinero sus negocios no podrían prosperar. Por suerte, ellas pudieron pagar las cuotas de sus préstamos pasados con comodidad. Un detalle importante es que en las comunidades rurales anteriormente las personas que daban créditos cobraban hasta un 10% al día. Es por eso que instituciones como Friendship Bridge ayuda mucho al desarrollo de la micro empresa ya que ahora las mujeres pueden tener acceso confiable al crédito.

Estas señoras por el momento están trabajando en el área de crianza de animales. Muchas de ellas están criando pollos, cerdos y toros. Los animales que crían depende de la demanda del mercado. Sin embargo el sueño de algunas es de aprender a elaborar pasteles y bocadillos y hacer manualidades. Esto se debe a que ellas quieren diversificar sus negocios para que así no tengan que depender de una fuente de ingresos. El sueño de otras es de pagar su crédito y poder sacar un préstamo que les ayude a comprar más ganado.

Este grupo de mujeres es muy entusiasta. Es por eso que le debemos de darles alas por medio de un préstamo. Ellas tienen la disposición de trabajar duro, ya que lo han hecho toda su vida para sobrevivir las duras condiciones de la pobreza. Apóyenlas en este proceso de desarrollo para que puedan salir adelante.

loans.use: Breeding of animals such as chickens, pigs and bulls.

loans.name: Leonilda

texts.en:
Leonilda has been a member of the El Roble community bank for the past 9 years. She is married, is 64 years old, and has 9 children.

Leonilda knits beautiful sweaters and bedspreads. She sells from her home and also fills special orders. Leonilda also travels to Lima to sell her products to clients that she already knows. She also rents out rooms, which generates additional income. Leonilda and her husband also dedicate themselves to harvesting coffee and cocoa in their land in the jungles of Ayacucho.

Leonilda needs a loan of 2,000 soles to buy thread and yarn. She plans to make her purchases in Lima, where she can find the lowest prices.

Leonilda´s hopes to build a third floor in her house, and to the rent rooms. She hopes that her children marry and that she can open her own store where she will sell food and display her knitted products.

loans.use: To buy thread and yarn.

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 47650

loans.name: Juana Maruja

texts.en:
Juana has been a member of the Alondras community bank for the past 8 years. She is 41 years old and a single mother of two daughters.

Juana sells clothing, sheets and blankets in the Nery García market. She buys her products in Nery García daily, and her sales are made on credit. Juana has another stand in Nery García where she sells various types of bread that she buys from different stores in the city of Huamanga.

Juana needs a loan of 3,000 soles ($1075 USD) to buy sweaters, blouses, bed spreads and blankets.

She hopes to build a house, dreams that her children are well educated, and hopes to own her own business selling potatoes.

loans.use: To buy sweaters, blouses, bed spreads and blankets.

loans.name: Julia America's Group

texts.en:
Janet, Julia, and Cenina have been part of the Alondras community bank for 8 months, 4 years, and 8 months respectively.

Janet is single. She is 18 years old and she studies administration at the local university. She uses a catalog to sell beauty products. Janet and her parents also own a vehicle that they use to provide public transportation.

Julia is a single mother. She is 58 years old and has 4 children. Julia has a grocery store that features public telephones in the store.

Cenina is married. She is 62 years old and has 6 children. She has her own grocery store where she sells vegetables. On weekends, she sells typical Ayacuchan food in her house.

Janet, Julia and Cenina need loans of 1000 soles (Janet), 1400 soles (Julia), and 600 soles (Cenina), which they will invest in rice, sugar, milk, ham, oil, and to maintain a car.

Janet, Julia and Cenina hope to have a business, a fleet of cars, and a large and fully stocked store.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, milk, ham, oil, and to maintain a car.

loans.name: Flor Del Cerro #1 Group

texts.es:
Flor del Cerro #1 is a group formed by women who all come from a place called Cerro de Oro (Gold Mountain), which is located in the outskirts of Atitlán Lake. Legend has is that the Mayans would extract gold from this mountain and that around this mountain, the sand was golden in color.

When one walks through the streets of Cerro de Oro, one can see that they are colored with the beautiful traditional outfits that the indigenous women wear daily. The streets are also adorned with the beautiful sound that the people produce when they speak the Maya-Tzutujil language, a dialect from the region.

Unfortunately, not everything is rose-colored in Cerro de Oro. Poverty and its consequences, such as malnutrition and illiteracy, are a great obstacle toward the development of the town. For this reason, Friendship Bridge decided to come to aid this town.

Despite the poverty in this region, the women of Flor de Cerro #1 are decided in working toward achieving a fulfilling life where they can meet the necessities of their families, and Friendship Bridge and Kiva are willing to support them.

All the women that belong to Flor del Cerro #1 work in the textile sector. Half of them are weavers and utilize their credit to purchase threads and weave the beautiful blouses they call huipiles that can be seen in the photograph. The other half uses their credit for the resale of clothing. They purchase traditional clothing whether it be huipiles, long skirts called cortes, aprons and shawls to later resell in the town, or American clothing, which they buy in the capital city.

Loans really make an impact in the lives of these women. Many of them have worked as laborers, store employees or housekeepers, earning an income that was barely enough to cover their expenses. However, with the loan, they are now entrepreneurs who own their own business. This is a radical change in their lives.

If we continue to help them, this change will become a reality. The reality they wish to live, which is to own a successful business with which they do not have to depend on a loan to be prosperous. With our help this dream can move forth…

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

Flor del Cerro #1 es un grupo conformado por mujeres que provienen de un lugar llamado Cerro de Oro. Cerro de Oro está ubicado a las orillas del Lago Atitlán. La leyenda dice que antiguamente los mayas extraían el oro de este cerro y que a las orillas de este hermoso cerro la arena era de color dorada.

Cuando uno camina por las calles de Cerro de Oro uno puede notar que ellas están pintadas con los bellos trajes tradicionales que lucen las mujeres indígenas todos los días. Las calles también estan ambientadas por el bellos sonido que producen las personas al hablar el idioma Maya-Tzutujil, un dialecto de es área.

Lastimosamente, en Cerro de Oro no todo es color de rosa, la pobreza y sus consecuencias como problemas de desnutrición y analfabetismo son un gran obstáculo para el desarrollo del pueblo. Es por eso que Friendship Bridge decidió incursionar en este lugar.

A pesar de la pobreza en el área las mujeres de Flor de Cerro #1 están decididas a luchar por conseguir una vida plena donde ellas y sus familias puedan satisfacer las necesidades de sus familias y Friendship Bridge y Kiva están dispuestos a apoyarlas.

Todas las clientes que pertenecen a Flor del Cerro #1 trabajan en el sector textil. La metida de ellas son tejedoras y ellas utilizan su crédito para comprar hilo y tejer las bellas blusas llamadas huipiles que están en las fotos. La otra parte utiliza su crédito para la reventa de ropa. Ellas compran ropa tradicional ya sea huipiles, faldas largas llamadas cortes, delantales y perrajes para luego revenderlos en el pueblo o ropa americana que la compran en la capital.

El crédito realmente causa un impacto en la vida de estas mujeres. Muchas de ellas han trabajando como mano de obra, empleadas de una tienda o domésticas ganando un sueldo que con las justas les alcanzaba para cubrir sus gastos. Sin embargo, ahora con el préstamo ellas ya son empresarias y tienen un negocio propio y esto es un cambio radical en sus vidas.

Si nosotros las seguimos ayudando este cambio va a poder convertirse en una realidad. La realidad que ellas quieren vivir, tener un negocio propio que sea exitoso y en el cual no tengan que depender de un préstamo para seguir adelante. Con nuestro apoyo este sueño se puede volver adelante…

loans.use: Compra de hilo para elaborar tejidos y bordados tradicionales, compra de ropa tradicional y americana para su venta

loans.name: Flor Del Cerro 2 Group

texts.es:
The women of the group called Flor del Cerro 2 are hardworking people. The reality of their lives makes any woman who wants to improve the quality of life for her family a real fighter. This group of women maintains the customs and traditions of Cerro de Oro. As you see in the photos, all of the women wear a traditional skirt with great pride, and most wear the traditional blouse. The mother tongue for these women is Maya Tzutujil, but many of them speak Spanish well.

All of the women work in textiles. Half of them used their loan to buy thread for making the traditional skirts. These skirts are the same as you see in the photos. The other half used the money to buy clothing to resell. Several of the women earn money buying and selling American style clothing, while others sell the traditional clothing.

One of the nice characteristics of this group is that the loan obligations are shared. They are all requesting similar amounts of money, and they are growing their businesses at the same time. This helps make it a cohesive group, as the women feel they are all more or less at the same level.

The women feel that it's important to work with the methodology of the communal banks, because other forms of credit wouldn't be available to them. The majority of them don't have much to use as collateral, so the loans via communal banks work well for them.

These women share the dream of improving the quality of life for their families. The situation in which they live is not ideal for the optimal development of their children, as the community lacks good services. This is why through Kiva, we can help these women realize their dreams and continue to help their families.

Translated by Kiva volunteer Emily Charnes

Las mujeres del grupo Flor del Cerro 2 son unas personas emprendedoras. La realidad en la que viven las mujeres en Cerro de Oro hace a cualquier mujer que quiere salir adelante junto con su familia una verdadera luchadora.

Este grupo de señoras mantienen las costumbres tradicionales de Cerro de Oro. Como se puede ver en la foto todas las señoras lucen su corte, o falda tradicional, con mucho orgullo, y todas excepto una lucen sus mágicos huipiles o blusas. La lengua materna de estas mujeres es el Maya Tzutujil, sin embargo algunas tienen la facilidad de desenvolverse bien en el idioma español.

Todas las señoras trabajan en el área textil. La mitad de ellas invierten su crédito en la compra de hilo para elaborar los huipiles tradicionales de Cerro de Oro. Estos huipiles se asemejan a los que ellas mismas lucen en la foto. La otra mitad de señoras invierten su crédito en la compra de ropa para su reventa. Algunas de ellas trabajan comprando y vendiendo ropa americana, mientras que otras revenden ropa tradicional.

Una de las buenas características de este grupo es que en general el rango de préstamos es reducido. Las mujeres están sacando una cantidad de dinero similar. Esto implica que las mujeres se están desarrollando empresarialmente al mismo tiempo. Este rasgo ayuda a la cohesión del grupo, ya que las mujeres sienten que todas están al mismo nivel.

Las señoras sienten que es realmente importante trabajar bajo la metodología de bancos comunales porque de otra forma ellas no podrían acceder a un crédito. La mayoría de ellas no tienen muchas pertenencias o escrituras que pueden dejar como colateral, es por eso que trabajar bajo esta metodología se les hace muy conveniente.

El sueño de estas mujeres es el de sacar a sus familias adelante. La situación en la que viven estas mujeres no es ideal para el óptimo desarrollo de sus hijos e hijas debido a la falta de buenos servicios en la comunidad. Es por eso que nosotros por medio de Kiva, las tenemos que ayudar para que ellas así puedan cumplir su sueño, sacar a su familia adelante.

loans.use: TO PURCHASE FABRIC AND THREAD FOR THEIR BUSINESSES MAKING TRADITIONAL CLOTHING,  AND ALSO TO INVEST IN MORE AMERICAN STYLE CLOTHING WHICH THEY RESELL.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Friendship Bridge - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Maya Tzutujil 1 Group

texts.es:
The communal bank Maya Tzutujil 1 has been working with Kiva partner Friendship Bridge for more than a year. Thanks to the good relationship they have with the institution, including facilitator María Quieju, the group has decided to take out another loan.

Within this communal bank, one can find enterprising women of all types – some resell American clothes and sell shoes via catalogue, others are weavers and jewelers, while another section embroiders typical regional blouses called “huipiles”.

The members are going to invest their portion of the loan in their distinctive areas. For example, the weavers are planning to purchase blue, purple and white threads to make huipiles. The embroiderers are planning to purchase threads of all colors to embroider birds, flowers and Mayan symbols on the blouses. Others will invest in the purchase of jewelry beads to make earrings, necklaces, purses, key chains, belts and bracelets. Meanwhile, another member is going to purchase American clothes in the capital to resell in Santiago de Atitlán.

Currently the women are working with another loan financed through “microfinanzas 9” in which they must repay it plus interest in stages every 42 days.

The group decided to opt for this kind of loan due to the fact that the work they do generates income only after some months have passed. For example, the weavers purchase the thread and then a month later they finish the blouse. The embroiderers can take between one and three months to complete their work. For the women who buy and sell American clothing, although they do that fairly quickly, with their margins it takes time for them to generate sufficient income to pay off their debts.

This group of women has already been working together and it’s important to keep supporting it. Their respective businesses have been slowly growing and if we support them now it’s possible for their small businesses to start to take off.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

El banco comunal Maya Tzutujil 1 ha venido trabajando con Friendship Bridge por más de un año. Debido a la buena relación que han tenido con la institución, por medio de la facilitadora María Quieju, ellas han decidido sacar otro préstamo.

Dentro de este banco comunal uno puede encontrar empresarias de todo tipo hay quienes revenden ropa americana y venden zapatos por catálogo, otras tejedoras, un grupo que bordan blusas típicas llamadas huipiles, joyeras

Las clientas van a invertir su crédito en distintas áreas. Por ejemplo las tejedoras están pensando en comprar hilos de colores celestes, morados y blancos para tejer huipiles. Las bordadoras están pensando en comprar hilos de todos los colores para bordar aves, flores y símbolos mayas. Otras van a invertir en comprar bolitas de mostacilla para elaborar aretes, collares, monederos, llaveros, cinturones y pulseras. Mientras que una clienta va a comprar ropa americana en la capital para luego revenderla en Santiago de Atitlán.

Actualmente, ellas están trabajando con el producto financiero “microfinanzas 9”. En este producto las mujeres tienen que repagar capital más interés en nueve plazos cada cuarenta y dos días.

Ellas decidieron optar por este producto debido a que el trabajo que tienen genera ingresos después de unos meses. Por ejemplo, las tejedoras compran el hilo y después de un mes terminan un huipil. Las artesanas que bordan huipiles pueden tomarse de uno a tres meses en bordar un huipil. Las mujeres que venden y compran ropa americana a pesar de comprar y vender de manera rápida la utilidad generada por venta es muy poco es por eso que necesitan tiempo para repagar su deuda.

Este grupo de mujeres ya ha venido trabajando juntos y es importante apoyarlas ya que tienen “viada”. Sus respectivos negocios han venido creciendo de a poquitos y si las apoyamos ahora cabe la posibilidad de que sus micro empresas despeguen. ¡Denles esa oportunidad!

loans.use: Purchase beads for jewelry; purchase thread to make and embroider traditional blouses / Comprar mostacilla para elaborar joyas, comprar hilo para elaborar tejidos y bordados tradicionales

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Friendship Bridge - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Maya Tzutujil 2 Group

texts.es:
The communal bank Maya Tzutujil 2 is made up of women native to Santiago de Atitlán. The beauty of this place is seen in the pretty clothing worn by the women and the men, to a small degree, when they walk down the gray main streets that make up this town with an unmatched history. Santiago de Atitlán was one of the pressure points during the region’s civil war to which many people fell victim. Of course, generations have since passed but the memory of the tragedies remains burned in the minds of the community elders.

As its name suggests, the members of this group belong are of Maya Tzutujil descent and their ancestors have lived for centuries in the extreme west of Lake Atitlán. Nowadays the Maya Tzutujil language is mainly spoken in the towns of Santiago de Atitlán, San Pablo la Iaguna, San Juan la Iaguna and San Pedro la Iaguna.

Like many women of Santiago de Atitlán, the members of this communal bank work in the textile, embroidery and bead-based jewelry trades.

Some of the members work weaving typical blouses of the region, called “huipiles”. These women plan to invest their money in the purchase of white, blue and purples threads — the typical colors used to make huipiles. Other members weave what are known as “perrajes”, which have a number of uses. Usually it’s used as part of an outfit and is worn as a sash across a women’s shoulder as a sign of respect. Women also wrap perrajes around their heads, as in the past it was worn on this way to be a weight buffer when carrying heavy baskets. Finally, when women go to a place of worship its used to cover their heads as a sign of respect.

Other group members will purchase thread to embroider beautiful birds and flowers on the aforementioned blouses, which can be seen in the photo. This type of embroidery is typical for the town. It is the only town where the women embroider birds in such a majestic way.

Finally, some of the other members will use the loan to purchase jewelry beads to make beautiful necklaces, bracelets, rings, earrings and key chains, which are made in very innovative shapes and change with the seasons. For example, during Christmas time the women make key chains of Santa Claus, reindeer, Christmas trees and the star of Bethlehem.

One can say that if he or she supports this group with its businesses he or she is also supporting the history, culture and art of Santiago de Atitlán thanks to the work of these women who dedicate themselves to express the magic of the town through their craftsmanship.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

El banco comunal Maya Tzutujil 2 está conformado por mujeres oriundas de Santiago de Atitlán. La belleza de Santiago de Atitlán yace en los hermosos trajes que lucen las mujeres y los hombres, a menor escala, cuando caminan por los estrechos caminos grisáceos que conforman un pueblo con una historia inigualable. Santiago de Atitlán fue uno de los focos de tensión durante la época de la guerra civil en la región de Atitlán. Muchas personas fueron victimas de aquel conflicto. Sin embargo, las generación pasan y el recuerdo de las tragedias se quedó archivado en la mente de los sabios ancianos de la comunidad.

Como su nombre lo especifica este grupo de mujeres pertenecen al grupo étnico Maya Tzutujil. Se sabe que los Mayas Tzutujiles han vivido por siglos en el extremo sur oeste del lago Atitlán. Actualmente los se escucha el idioma Maya Tzutujil mayormente en los pueblos de Santiago de Atitlan, San Pablo la laguna, San Juan la laguna y San Pedro la laguna.

Como muchas mujeres en Santiago de Atitlan las clientes que participan en este banco comunal trabajan en tejidos, bordados y la elaboración de joyas hechas en base de mostacilla.

Un grupo de las clientes trabajan tejiendo huipiles o blusas típicas. Ellas van a invertir su dinero en la compra de hilo blanco, celeste, morado y celeste. Estos son los colores típicos utilizado a la hora de fabricar el huipil. Otras tejen perrajes. Un perraje es una pieza de tela multiuso. Usualmente es utilizado como parte de la indumentaria y esta sobrepuesta en el hombro de las mujeres para indicar respeto a los demás, también las mujeres envuelven el perraje y se lo ponen entre la cabeza y los pesados canastos que cargan sobre la cabeza para amortiguar el peso. Finalmente, cuando las mujeres van a la iglesia o al templo se cubren la cabeza con el perraje en símbolo de respeto.

Otro grupo de clientas va a comprar hilo para bordar hermosas aves y flores en los huipiles, así como se pueden ver en la foto. Este tipo de bordado es típico de este pueblo. Es el único pueblo en donde las mujeres bordan aves de una manera tan majestuosa.

Finalmente, otro grupo de clientes utiliza el crédito para comprar bolitas de mostacilla. Con la mostacilla ellas elaboran bellos collares, pulseras, anillos, aretes y llaveros. Los llaveros tienden a ser figuras muy innovadoras y acorde con la fecha del año. Por ejemplo, en la época de navidad las mujeres producen llaveros de Santa Claus, venados, árboles de Navidad y estrellas fugaces.

Uno puede decir que si uno apoya a estas mujeres con sus negocios uno también está apoyando la historia, la cultura y el arte de Santiago de Atitlan debido a que estas artesanas se dedican a expresar por medio de su arte la magia de este pueblo.

loans.use: Purchase threads to weave and embroider traditional blouses; purchase beads to make jewelry / Compra de hilo para elaborar tejidos y bordados, compra de mostacilla para elaborar joyas

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Friendship Bridge - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Estrellas De Atitlan Group

texts.es:
The group "The Stars of Atitlan" has worked with Kiva partner The Friendship Bridge for many years. They are one of the oldest most accomplished communal banks the organization has, and the members are very proud of that fact. They definitely feel a strong affection for the organization and vice versa. The group meets every 42 days in the house of Adela R. to get their training, repay their debts or deposit their savings. There is a happy and responsible ambiance in Adela's home, due to the fact that all the members of an accomplished history.

What they most like about working under a communal bank system is that, thanks to being a group of women with a good record, they are assured access to loans and avoid any red tape. They also enjoy sharing experiences with each other. With respect to The Friendship Bridge, they group feels its a good institution that is trustworthy, gives out loans quickly and has good customer service. They are also satisfied with the training they receive, among the courses the group highlights as especially helpful are business administration, medicinal plants, women's health and family planning, which is particularly stressed because it can have such an impact on their lives. Keep in mind that in rural areas families can become very large and as a consequence it can result in the families falling further into poverty.

Santiago de Atitlan is a place known for the ability of its artisans. The most beautiful bead-based jewelry in the region comes from there. By luck, this group has two members who work in this trade. They will invest their loans in the purchase of beads to make necklaces, bracelets and earrings. Two of the women work in textiles, weaving tradition blouses called "huipiles", while another member embroiders these items with beautiful birds, roses or Mayan symbols. Adela, a woman of strong character and playful at the same time like many women on the Guatemalan coast, sells snacks and American clothing. Finally, Karla R. has a cosmetics business. She buys her items via catalogue and sells them door to door. "The Stars of Atitlan" is a group that empowers all of its members. The members a group that has congealed over time and that works very well together. Due to this, it's imperative that The Friendship Bridge and Kiva members work together to support this group of talented, hard-working women.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Las Estrellas de Atitlan han venido trabajando con Friendship Bridge por muchos años. Son uno de los bancos comunales más antiguos y más cumplidos que tiene la institución y ellas se sienten muy orgullosas de eso. Ellas definitivamente sienten una afiliación fuerte con la institución y viceversa. Las Estrellas se juntan cada 42 días en la casa de doña Adela R. R. para recibir sus capacitaciones y repagar su deuda o depositar su ahorro. En la casa de Adela hay un ambiente de alegría y de responsabilidad. Esto se debe a que todas las mujeres tienen una tradición de ser cumplidas.

Lo que más les gusta de trabajar bajo la metodología de bancos comunales es que debido a que tienen un grupo de mujeres cumplidas ellas se aseguran el acceso a crédito y se evitan el gran problema de la mora. Asimismo, les gusta compartir experiencias de la vida entre ellas. Con respecto a Friendship Bridge, ellas sienten que es una buena institución debido a que es confiable, entrega el crédito rápido y tiene buen servicio al cliente gracias a la labor de la compañera Maria Q.. De la misma manera, ellas se sienten contentas porque reciben capacitaciones. Las mujeres contaron que las capacitaciones que más le gustaron fueron las de administración del negocio, plantas medicinales, salud de la mujer y planificación familiar. Las clientes hicieron hincapié en la charla de planificación ya que si les creo un impacto en sus vidas. Vale recordar, que en las áreas rurales las familias pueden llegar a ser muy extensas y como consecuencia esto puede resultar en que a las familias le cueste salir más de la pobreza.

Santiago de Atitlan es un lugar reconocido por la capacidad de sus artesanas. En este lugar se produce una de las joyas, en base a mostacilla, más bellas de la región. Por suerte, en este grupo tenemos dos clientas que trabajan en ese rubro. Ellas invierten su crédito en comprar bolitas de mostacilla para elaborar collares, brazaletes y aretes. Dos señoras trabajan con tejidos. Dos trabajan elaborando los huipiles, las blusas tradicionales de Guatemala, mientras que una señora borda los huipiles. Ella borda los huipiles con bellos pájaros, rosas o símbolos mayas. Doña Adela una mujer de carácter fuerte y alegre al mismo tiempo, muy típico de las mujeres de la costa de Guatemala, vende refacciones y ropa americana. Finalmente, Karla R. trabaja en el negocio de cosméticos. Ella compra cosméticos por catálogo y los vende de casa en casa.

Las Estrellas de Atitlán es un grupo que amerita el apoyo de todos. Es un grupo que se ha consolidado a lo largo del tiempo y que han trabajado muy bien. Debido a eso, es importante que Friendship Bridge y ustedes por medio de Kiva apoyen a este grupo de mujeres talentosas, aguerridas y trabajadoras.

loans.use: Purchase beads to make jewelry; purchase threads to make and embroider blouses; purchase American clothing and food ingredients; and purchase cosmetics / Compra de mostacilla para elaborar joyas, compra de hilos para elaborar tejidos y bordados, compra de ropa americana, ingredientes de comida y cosméticos

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Friendship Bridge - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Hortencia Group

texts.es:
In secluded Aldea Tzucubal, Guatemala, a group of women united to form Las Hortencias communal bank. This group began working with Kiva partner The Friendship Bridge Guatemala last year, and thanks to their success they decided to ask for another loan — and another opportunity — with the organization.

The members of this group are weavers, and as you can see in the photo, they wear their own works of art: typical regional blouses, called "Huipiles", which come mainly from the Nahualá region of Guatemala. The technique used to make these articles is extremely complex due to the large variety of designs and patterns.

The women plan to use the loan in the most wise way, investing 100 percent of it in the purchase of fabrics and thread to make their products. They also play to purchase other huipiles to resell in their village or the local market.

These women are constantly thinking about moving up in life. They would like to see their business be able to grow thanks to the loan and their hard work, since they need a large amount of earnings to able to achieve their dreams. The goal of this group is to see their children be successful by means of a good education. The women hope that their sons and daughters will be able to attend college. They also dream of expanding their business to the point where they can to pay off their debt so their success would not be dependent on outside capital.

Along with being a relatively young group, the women think that working as a communal bank is great because they have been able to get to know one another. They are also able to take advantage of the training that The Friendship Bridge Guatemala offers.

Living in a rural community in Guatemala is not easy work, much less if one is trying to start a business. It's for this reason that we need to lend his group of hard-working women a hand so they are able to keep moving forward.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

En la retirada Aldea Tzucubal se reúnen las mujeres que conforman el banco comunal las Hortencias. Este grupo de mujeres empezó con The Friendship Bridge Guatemala el año pasado. Debido al éxito de su negocio decidieron pedir un nuevo crédito, una nueva oportunidad, con la institución. Las integrantes de este grupo son tejedoras y como se puede ver en la foto, estas señoras lucen sus propias obras de arte: blusas típicas, llamadas huipiles, mayormente de la región de Nahualá. La técnica utilizada para elaborar aquellos huipiles es extremadamente compleja debido a la gran variedad de diseños y puntadas. Ellas piensan utilizar su crédito de la manera más sabia, invertir 100% del crédito en la compra de materia prima, hilo, para la elaboración de sus productos. También, piensan en comprar huipiles para poder revenderlos en su aldea o en el mercado local. Estas señoras están constantemente pensando en superarse. A ellas les gustaría que gracias a su crédito y esfuerzo su negocio pueda crecer, ya que ellas necesitan la mayor cantidad de ganancias para lograr sus sueños. El sueño de este grupo de mujeres es de sacar sus hijos adelante por medio de los estudios. Ellas desean que sus hijos puedan asistir al colegio. También sueñan en agrandar su negocio a tal punto donde ellas puedan amortizar su deuda y no sean dependiente de capital externo para tener un negocio exitoso. A pesar de ser un grupo relativamente joven, ellas piensan que trabajar bajo la metodología de bancos comunales es grandioso debido a que ellas han logrado conocer y entenderse entre todas. Asimismo, ellas se entretienen mucho durante las capacitaciones que The Friendship Bridge Guatemala les ofrece. Vivir en una comunidad rural en Guatemala no es una tarea fácil y más aun si uno está tratando de empezar con un negocio. Es por eso, que nosotros tenemos que brindarles una mano a este grupo de señoras para que ellas puedan salir adelante junto con nuestro esfuerzo

loans.use: Purchase fabric  and thread to make traditional garments / compra de hilo para elaborar tejidos tradicionales

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Friendship Bridge - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Molino Belen Group

texts.es:
Purchase of linen to elaborate dresses and traditional embroideries, Purchase of clothes, purchase of vegetables

Close to the departmental header of the Sololá department live women who shape the communal bank Molino Belen. Some live in the back of the hospital near the front of their village and others live near a little school. In spite of the fact that they live relatively separated from one another, a sense of unity among the whole is felt during their reunions.

Unity inside a communal bank is of utmost importance. The functioning of this style of work is based on the idea of social collateral. Every member of the group backs other members among them. Additionally, the good relations between the women create awareness of payment. For example, unity in the group then a woman in the group will think twice before choosing not to pay because she will not want to jeopardize the reputation of the communal bank amidst the institution. If a client does not pay then the whole group is affected and this could create various negative repercussions. This is why solidarity in the group is important so that this system functions in the best manner possible.

In this group, the women work primarily in the textile area. Three women are weavers. They utilize their credit to buy thread to elaborate typical items that are sold in the market. Two of the women also utilize their credit to buy thread, however they employ it in the art of embroidery. They embroider huipiles and the cuts, which are large traditional skirts. Three clients invest their credit in upbringing animals. One of the clients invest their credit by reselling clothes and the last client invests her credit by buying vegetables to later resell them in the Sololá market.

The advantage of these women is that they live very close to the Sololá market. In this market, there is much commercialization of agricultural products and crafts. During the days of the market, Tuesday and Thursday, the people begin to sell their products at one in the morning and there are people who finish selling at four in the morning. The Sololá market is very dynamic—it attracts traders from nearby villages like Panajachel, Concepción, San Jorge, among others.

The women believe that solicited loans have served them greatly because they have been able to enlarge their business to the point where they can now generate utilities. This is due in major part to the fact that with credit, they can buy inputs necessary so they can be rentable.

The women comment that the loans have helped them improve themselves because they now have a proper business and with the utilities that they generate they can dress, educate, and nourish their children.

If this is not a good enough reason to approve these ladies then I cannot think of another! These women work hard for the wellbeing of their children. We must learn to value people like these in the world now that in this world of consumerism we face people who do not help others. Support these women!

Cerca de la cabecera departamental del departamento de Sololá viven las mujeres que conforman el banco comunal Molino Belen. Algunas viven a la espalda del hospital a la entrada del pueblo y otras viven a la par de una escuelita. A pesar de que viven relativamente separadas una vez en las reuniones se siente la unidad del grupo.

La unidad dentro de un banco comunal es de suma importancia. El funcionamiento de este estilo de trabajo se basa en la idea de colateral social. Todas las integrante del grupo se avalan entre ellas. Además, la buena relación entre las mujeres crea conciencia de pago. Por ejemplo, si hay unidad en el grupo entonces una mujer va a pensar dos veces antes de no pagar porque ella no va a querer perjudicar la reputación del banco comunal ante la institución. Si una clienta no paga el grupo entero cae en mora y esto puede crear varias repercusiones negativas. Es por eso, que la solidaridad del grupo es realmente importante para que este funcione de la mejor manera.

En este grupo las mujeres trabajan mayormente en el área textil. Tres señoras son tejedoras. Ellas utilizan su crédito para comprar hilos para elaborar piezas típicas que son vendidas en el mercado. Dos de ellas, también utilizan su crédito para comprar hilo, sin embargo ellas lo emplean en el arte de bordado. Ellas bordan los huipiles y los cortes, faldas largas tradicionales. Tres clientas invierten su crédito en la crianza de animales. Una invierte el crédito revendiendo ropa y la última comprando verduras para luego venderlas en el mercado de Sololá.

La ventaja de estas mujeres es que viven muy cerca del mercado de Solola. En este mercado hay mucha comercialización de productos agropecuarios y artesanales. Durante los días de mercado, martes y viernes, la gente empieza a vender sus productos a la una de la mañana y hay personas que terminan su venta a las cuatro de la mañana. El mercado de Solola es muy dinámico ya que atrae a los comerciantes de pueblos aledaños como Panajachel, Concepción, San Jorge, entre otros.

Las mujeres creen que los préstamos solicitados les ha servido de mucho debido a que ellas han podido agrandar su negocio a un punto donde ya pueden generar utilidades. Esto se debe mayormente a que con el crédito ellas pueden comprar los insumos necesarios para que sean rentables.

Las señoras comentan que los préstamos las han ayudado a superarse porque ellas ya tienen un negocio propio y con las utilidades que ellas generan ellas pueden vestir, educar y alimentar a sus hijos.

¡Si esta no es una razón para apoyar a estas señoras entonces no se me ocurre otra! Estas mujeres se dan íntegramente para conseguir el bienestar de sus hijos. Nosotros tenemos que valorar gente así en el mundo ya que en este mundo de consumismo cada vez nos topamos con gente que se desvive por el prójimo. ¡Apóyenlas!

loans.use: Compra de hilo para elaborar trajes y bordados tradicionales, compra de ropa, compra de verduras,

loans.name: Santa Veneranda

texts.en:
Santa Veneranda is a thirty-one year old entrepreneur who owns and operates a clothing store in the Don Gregorio community of San Cristobal.  Her husband and she have three sons and one daughter, all of whom go to school.
A couple of months ago, Santa Veneranda took a loan from FSMA which she invested to add to a collection of fashionable clothing to her stock.  According to the entrepreneur, this strategy was worth its weight in gold since more people have started to visit her small store and she has gotten a lot of new customers.  Veneranda says her business is profitable, and she wants to keep running it in a similar fashion so that she can earn more income.

The well experienced businesswoman explains that will use this new loan to buy a larger showcase for her store.  She will also buy also new clothing to add to her stock.  Santa Veneranda hopes that before long she will become one of the most known suppliers of these goods in her community.

loans.use: Purchase of a larger showcase and more clothing to add to her stock.

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
Justina is a fifty-year-old entrepreneur and a proud mother of three sons that are in university.  Her husband passed away six months ago, and since then she has been obliged to support her sons' education on her own.  Justina explains that it is difficult for her sons to get a good job, and they cannot pay for their university studies.

Justina operates a small cafeteria which she started three years ago.  She’s requesting a loan to purchase materials in order to keep preparing her delicious hamburgers, cheeseburgers and natural juices for her growing clientele.
Justina would like to have money enough so as to improve her family’s lifestyle.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials to keep preparing food for a small cafeteria.

loans.name: Solanyi

texts.en:
Solanyi is a brave woman who works hard to fend for her two sons aged seven and twelve years old.  Solanyi sells women’s clothing in the Don Gregorio community of San Cristobal.  According to her,  this business has been the principal source of income for her family over the last five years.   

Currently, Solanyi plans to increase her inventory to increase her sales.  As her children are growing, it is becoming much more difficult for her to make her ends meet.

She hopes that this loan (the fifth she’ll receive from FSMA) will help her move her business forward and provide a comfortable lifestyle for her family.

loans.use: Purchase of more clothing to add to her stock.

loans.name: Nuevo Dia Group

texts.es:
The community bank Nuevo Día is a young bank that started 4 months ago. At the moment, it has 2 investment cycles and 20 members.

The members have different businesses like selling prepared meals, clothes, grains, vegetables, groceries, games, crafts, potatoes, small animals as well as offering tailoring services.

Each member has a different background. Maricruz, for example, runs a tailor shop and beauty salon in the same premises.

Elizabeth, for instance, sells groceries in various markets in the region as well as surgical clothing for well established customers.

The members request different amounts of loans: some 400, others 600, 800 or 1000 soles for a total amount of 9600 soles through the community bank.

The loans will be used to purchase surgical clothes, pants, chicken, tomatoes, pumpkin, potatoes, cloth, meat, rice, sugar, and also to furbish their shops with armchairs and mirrors.

The dreams of the members of the community bank are to have flourishing and stable businesses, to build houses and to be able to provide a good education for their children.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

El Banco Comunal Nuevo Día es un banco joven que se inició hace 4 meses. Actualmente tiene 2 ciclos y 20 socias.

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta de comida, ropa, cereales, verduras, abarrotes, juguetes, artesanía, papa, animales menores y servicios de confección de prendas de vestir.

Cada socia tiene una historia diferente como es el caso de Maricruz que tiene un taller de confección de prendas de vestir y también un salón de belleza en un mismo local.

Por otro lado Elizabeth vende abarrotes en las diferentes ferias de la región y además vende ropa quirúrgica a clientes ya establecidos.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos de préstamos, algunos montos son de 400 soles, 600 soles, 800 soles, 1000 soles haciendo un total de 9,600 soles de préstamos en el Banco Comunal.

Los préstamos lo invertirán en la compra de ropa quirúrgica, pantalones, pollo, tomate, zapallo, papa, telas, carne, arroz, azúcar y para implementar su local con sillones, espejos.

Los sueños de las socias son que sus negocios prosperen, tener un negocio estable, construir su casa y que sus hijos tengan una buena educación.

loans.use: The loans will be used to purchase surgical clothes, pants, chicken, tomatoes, pumpkin, potatoes, cloth, meat, rice, sugar, and also to furbish their shops with armchairs and mirrors.

loans.name: Sonia's Group

texts.es:
Daniela, Sonia and Elsa are members of the community bank Ccatun Sacha, which means “Big Tree” in Quechua.

Daniela is 25 years old, is married and has 2 children. She travels two times a week to the different markets of the region where she buys grains. Daniela sells them later in the markets of the city of Ayacucho. With her loan, she will buy two cell-phones in order to offer phone calls.

Sonia is 27 years old, is married and has 2 children. She sells groceries and fruits in a small market close to her home.

Elsa is 37 years old, has a partner but no children. She buys animals in the different markets of the region and sells their meat to butcher’s shops. In addition, Elsa breeds goats.

Daniela, Sonia and Elsa request loans of 1000, 600 and 1000 soles. They will use the money to buy cell-phones, rice, soap, eggs and goats.

The dreams of Daniela, Sonia and Elsa are to have a big shop, some own capital, to improve their housing and to buy a car.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

Daniela, Sonia y Elsa son socias del Banco Comunal Ccatun Sacha que significa “Árbol Grande” en quechua.

Daniela es casada, tiene 25 años y 2 hijos, Daniela viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región 2 veces por semana donde compra cereales, que posteriormente vende en los mercados de la ciudad de Ayacucho. Daniela con el préstamo que obtendrá comprará dos equipos celulares para brindar servicios de llamadas telefónicas.

Por otro lado Sonia es casada, tiene 27 años y 2 hijos, Sonia vende abarrotes en un mercadillo cercano a su casa, además vende frutas.

Mientras que Elsa es conviviente, tiene 37 años y aun no tiene hijos, Elsa vende carne, los animales los adquiere en las diferentes ferias de la región y luego lo beneficia, la carne lo vende al por mayor a las carnicerías. Además Elsa se dedica a la crianza de ganado caprino.

Daniela, Sonia y Elsa necesitan préstamos de 1000 soles, 600 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de equipos celulares, arroz, azúcar, jabón, huevo y ganado caprino.

Los sueños de Daniela, Sonia y Elsa son tener una tienda grande, capital propio, mejorar su casa y comprar un carro.

loans.use: Daniela, Sonia and Elsa request loans of 1000, 600 and 1000 soles. They will use the money to buy cell-phones, rice, soap, eggs and goats.

loans.name: Irma's Group

texts.es:
Marleni, Irma and Maribel are members of the Ccatun Sacha Community Bank, meaning «Great Tree» in the quechua language.

Marlenis lives with her common law spouse, is 24 years old and has 2 kids. Marleni sells fruits from house to house in her neighbourhood, a job that she keeps from Monday to Friday. Marleni also sells clothing, and school bags on Saturdays and Sundays in the San Juan market.

Irma is married, she is 24 years old and has 2 kids. Irma sells prepared foods at the final stop of a transport company, and she also sells clothing on credit to clients that she knows well.

Maribel is a single mom, is 27 years old and has 1 child. Maribel sells cosmetics by catalogue and she also works in a drug store.

Marleni, Irma and Maribel request loans in the amounts of 800 soles, 1600 soles, and 200 soles to invest in the purchase of school bags, fruits, kids clothing, slacks, soft drinks, cosmetics and perfumes.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Marleni, Irma y Maribel son socias del Banco Comunal Ccatun Sacha que significa “Árbol Grande” en quechua.

Marleni es conviviente, tiene 24 años y 2 hijos, Marleni vende frutas de manera ambulatoria cerca de su casa, actividad que realiza de lunes a viernes. Además Marleni vende ropa, mochilas los días sábados y domingos en la feria de San Juan.

Por otro lado Irma es casada, tiene 24 años y 2 hijos, Irma vende comida en el ultimo paradero de una empresa de transportes, además Irma vende ropa a crédito que reparte a clientes ya establecidos.

Mientras que Maribel es madre soltera, tiene 27 años y 1 hijo, Maribel vende cosméticos por catalogo y además Maribel trabaja en una botica.

Marleni, Irma y Maribel necesitan préstamos de 800 soles, 1600 soles, 200 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de mochilas, frutas, conjuntos para niños, pantalones, gaseosas, cosméticos y perfumes.

Los sueños de Marleni, Irma y Maribel son tener un negocio grande, una vidriería, una tienda de ropa y sus hijos estudien.

loans.use: Marleni, Irma and Maribel  request loans in the amount o 800 soles, 1600 soles, and 200 soles, monies that will be invested in the purchase of school bags, fruits, children's clothing, slacks, soft drinks, cosmetics and perfumes.

loans.name: Flora Dolores

texts.es:
Flora is a member of the Victoria Community Bank.

Flora is married and is 38 years old with 4 children. Flora has a grocery store where she also sells meats, vegetables, and liquors, a job that she keeps with the help of her children. Flora also has a car and provides local transportation in the city of Ayacucho.

Flora needs a loan in the amount of 3000 soles that she will invest in the purchase of new tires for her car.

Flora's dream is to provide her children with a good education so that they may grow up to be professionals, improve her businesses and purchase another car.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Flora es socia del Banco Comunal Victoria.

Flora es casada, tiene 38 años y 4 hijos, Flora tiene una tienda donde vende abarrotes, carne, verduras, licores, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de sus hijos. Además Flora tiene un carro que trabaja realizando transporte urbano en la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Flora necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de llantas para su carro.

Los sueños de Flora son brindar una buena educación a sus hijos para que sean profesionales, mejorar sus negocios y comprar otro carro.

loans.use: Flora requests a loan in the amount of 3000 soles to invest in the purchase of tires for her car.

payments.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business 47666

loans.name: Maria Dalila

texts.es:
Maria is a member of the Victoria Community Bank.

Maria is married and she is 41 years old with two children. Maria sells CDs and DVDs from her home and she also sells in the markets in the city of Ayachuco. She also travels to different provinces in the country but her products she gets from the city of Lima.

Maria requests a loan in the amount of 2500 soles to invest in the purchase of CDs and DVDs.

Maria's dream is to expand her business to incluD. the sales of artifcats and to have a store and build a house.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva volunteer.

Maria es socia del Banco Comunal Victoria.

Maria es casada, tiene 41 años y 2 hijos, Maria venD. Cds, Dvds, al por mayor y menor, sus ventas lo realiza en su casa y también reparte a los diferentes mercados, tiendas D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho, también viaja a provincias del departamento, sus productos son adquiridos en la ciudad D. Lima.

Maria necesita un préstamo D. 2500 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. Cds, Dvd.

Los sueños D. Maria son ampliar su negocio, vender artefactos, tener una tienda y construir su casa.

loans.use: Maria requests a loan in the amount of 2500 soles to invest in the purchase of CDs and DVDs.

loans.name: Diana's Group

texts.es:
Ines, Diana, and Marina are members to the Victoria Community Bank.

Ines is a single mom, is 35 years old and has 3 children. Ines sells cheese that she brings from the Alpachaca community, selling her products from store to store. Ines also cleans houses and provides laundry services. With the loan she will obtain Ines will purchase a cart to sell a chicken dish called salchipollo.

Diana lives with her common law spouse, is 22 years old and she is pregnant with their first child. She sells fish in the fish market in the city of Ayacucho, bringing in her products from Lima.

Marina is married, she is 42 years old and has 2 children. Marina sells prepared foods from her home, and she also has a small grocery store.

Ines, Diana and Marina need loans in the amount of 900 soles, 750 soles, and 1000 soles, monies that will be invested in the purchase of fish, lentils, rice, milk, detergents, and a cart.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Ines, Diana y Marina pertenecen al Banco Comunal Victoria.

Ines es madre soltera, tiene 35 años y 3 hijos, Ines vende quesos que trae de la comunidad de Alpachaca, sus productos lo vende ambulatoriamente a tiendas, además Ines hace limpieza y lava ropa ajena. Ines con el préstamo que obtendrá tiene proyectado comprar una carreta para vender salchipollo.

Por otro lado Diana es conviviente, tiene 22 años y esta embarazada de su primer hijo, Diana vende pescado en el terminal pesquero de la ciudad de Ayacucho, sus productos lo adquiere de la ciudad de Lima.

Mientras que Marina es casada, tiene 42 años y 2 hijos, Marina vende comida en su casa, además tiene una tienda de abarrotes.

Ines, Diana y Marina necesitan préstamos de 900 soles, 750 soles, 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de pescados, lenteja, arroz, leche, detergente y una carreta.

Los sueños de Inés, Diana y Marina son tener un trabajo seguro, sus hijos estudien, tener una tienda de abarrotes, construir su casa.

loans.use: Ines, Diana and Marina request a loan in the amounts of 900 soles, 750 soles, and 1000 soles to invest in the purchase of  fish, lentils, rice, milk, detergent, and a cart.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 24, 2008)
Correction due to underpayment for business 47668

loans.name: Haydee's Group

texts.es:
Angélica and Hayde belong to the Bonanza Communal Bank.

Angélica, 51 years old, is a single mother with one child. She sells cereals at the “12 de Abril” market. During the holiday season, she also bakes breads and makes typical jams.

Hayde is a 59 years old widower with two children. She sells second hand clothes at the different regional fairs.

Angélica and Hayde need loans for 800 and 200 soles, respectively, which they will invest in the purchase of barley, wheat, garbanzo beans, lentils, and second hand clothes.

The dreams of Angélica and Hayde are to see their children become professionals, to own a house in the city’s downtown and to have their own capital.

Translated from Spanish by Leticia Britos, Kiva Volunteer.

Angélica y Hayde pertenecen al Banco Comunal Bonanza.

Angélica es madre soltera, tiene 51 años y un hijo. Angélica vende cereales en el mercado 12 de abril, y además elabora panes y dulces típicos de la zona, actividad que realiza solo en época de fiestas.

Mientras que Haydee es viuda, tiene 59 años y dos hijos. Haydee vende ropa usada en las diferentes ferias de la región.

Angélica y Hayde necesitan préstamos de 800 y 200 soles, respectivamente, dinero que será invertido en la compra de cebada, trigo, garbanzo y lenteja, y ropa usada.

Los sueños de Angélica y Haydee son que sus hijos sean profesionales, tener una casa en el centro de la ciudad y capital propio.

loans.use: Purchase of barley, wheat, garbanzo beans, lentils, and second hand clothes.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.es:
Zenaida, a 20 years old single mother of one child, belongs to the Bonanza Communal Bank. She sells groceries at home, in Pantipampa, two hours away from the city of Ayacucho. She also cultivates potatoes in her land, which she then sells at the markets in the city of Lima. Finally, she breeds animals.

She needs a loan for 3000 soles, which she will invest in the purchase of rice, sugar, oil, candies, sodas and beer.

Zenaida’s dreams are to buy a house in Ayacucho, improve her business and provide her daughter with a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Leticia Britos, Kiva Volunteer.

Zenaida, madre soltera de 20 años, con una hija, es socia del Banco Comunal Bonanza. Ella vende abarrotes en su casa, ubicada en Pantipampa, a 2 horas de la ciudad de Ayacucho. Además, Zenaida siembra papa en sus terrenos, que posteriormente vende en los mercados de la ciudad de Lima. También se dedica a la crianza de animales.

Zenaida necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar, aceite, golosinas, gaseosa y cerveza.

Los sueños de Zenaida son comprar una casa en Ayacucho, mejorar su negocio y brindar una buena educación a su hija.

loans.use: Purchase of rice, sugar, oil, candies, sodas and beer.
